Issue.title: Issue
Issue.description: Represents an IT issue reported by a user.

userId.description: Reference to the User who reported the issue. (Relationship: User 1:N Issue)

issueType.description: The general category of the issue.

customIssueType.description: A user-defined issue type, if 'Other' is selected.

status.description: Current status of the issue (e.g., Open, In Progress, Resolved).

priority.description: Priority level of the issue (e.g., High, Medium, Low).

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the issue was reported.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the issue was last updated.

attachments.description: Links to attachments related to the issue.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the IssueTrackr application.

role.description: Role of the user (e.g., User, Admin).

definition.description: Stores user profiles. Listing of users is disabled to prevent unauthorized access. The 'userId' parameter represents the unique identifier for a user.

Stores issues reported by a specific user. The 'userId' parameter represents the owner of the issue, ensuring path-based ownership. The `issueId` parameter represents the unique identifier for an issue within a user's issues.

params.name: userId
params.description: Unique identifier for the user who owns the issue.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to ensure Authorization Independence, DBAC, and support secure list operations (QAPs). It leverages structural segregation and consistent access modeling for clarity and maintainability.

*   **Users Collection:** Stores user profiles. Listing users is disabled to prevent unauthorized data access.
*   **User-Owned Issues:** Issues are stored in a subcollection `/users/{userId}/issues/{issueId}`. This establishes clear ownership and simplifies security rules. This approach guarantees that listing issues is always scoped to a specific user.

This structure avoids `get()` calls in security rules by directly associating issues with their owners, ensuring Authorization Independence. QAPs are satisfied through path-based ownership, allowing secure and efficient data retrieval for each user.
